awd_abstract_narration:
Technical Description: A fundamental approach in materials science involves the fabrication of new materials that couple properties in heterogeneous structures. Transistors for logic devices use the transport of charge in a semiconductor to process information.  There are now alternate proposals to use the electron spin to process information, both to reduce power consumption of and add functionality (such as memory) to the transistor.   Currently silicon and germanium are widely used as a channel material because they transport charge well, and these semiconductors also transport spin very efficiently. This project focuses on coupling spin from a ferromagnetic oxide to germanium through an insulating oxide barrier.  This novel materials system is being developed using atomic layer synthesis by molecular beam epitaxy to manipulate and control spin tunneling into germanium through chemical and structural modifications of the interfaces.  Using atomic layer control, key aspects of the interfaces can be manipulated to control spin coupling.  These include chemical composition, electric polarization, strain, atomic layer termination, and band offset.  Both the physical and electronic structures of each layer are characterized using a combination of in- situ x-ray photoemission spectroscopy, synchrotron x-ray diffraction, x-ray absorption spectroscopy, and transmission electron microscopy.  The fully epitaxial design enables the understanding of structural properties governing the function of a promising spin-based device platform.

Non-technical Description: New materials are required to develop new electronic devices for computing applications.  These new materials are designed to either require less power or offer additional function in microprocessors.  The strategy of the project is to use the spin of an electron as a bit of information rather than charge, as is currently done.  The project synthesizes new materials that manipulate electron spin by stacking thin films together one atomic layer at a time. The positions of the atoms are determined using x-ray facilities at the National Laboratories.  As part of this work, students and young technicians will be trained in state of the art semiconductor technology,  preparing them for careers in the semiconductor industries.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this project centers on advancing semiconductor technology using state-of-the-art materials synthesis methods, which enable the integration of multi-functional materials with mainstream semiconductors for transformational applications in microelectronics. This project has led to a methodology to deposit specific classes of high-quality crystalline oxides directly on conventional semiconductors, one atomic layer at a time. This technological advance has led to the realization of multiple prototypical devices that hold potential for modern electronics applications. One key achievement of this project is the demonstration of an electrically controllable spintronics device based on this crystalline oxide-semiconductor platform. A spintronics device uses the spin degree of freedom of an electron to carry information and perform logic operations. Since no net charge flow is required, spintronics has the potential advantage over traditional charge-based devices of offering enhanced energy efficiency and reduced power consumption. In our device, injection of spin can be turned on or off by adjusting an external voltage, thus providing a promising route toward large-scale integration of microprocessors for spin-based computing. Another contribution of this project has been the development of a highly efficient, oxide-stabilized architecture for solar fuel production from water. We have coupled the unique properties of functional oxides to semiconductor solar cells,  protecting the solar-active surface from corrosion and degradation under ambient conditions. While other materials have been used to stabilize the solar-active surface, they often require precious metal catalysts such as platinum to facilitate reaction kinetics. Our approach represents a step toward a catalyst-free solar cell for unassisted water splitting and hydrogen production.

The broader impacts of this project include the development of a course targeted at both undergraduate and graduate students on understanding key concepts of advanced X-ray and electron-based techniques used in materials research. This course is made possible via collaboration between Yale and Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL), where experts from BNL come to Yale to give lectures and provide students with a view of research projects conducted at BNL. This collaboration has facilitated the development of beamlines at NSLS II. This project has also offered research opportunities to students through a Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) program, where students from other universities join the group in summer conducting research. Students also participate in the Family Science Nights program, where they visit local primary schools and demonstrate simple physics experiments to children and their families, motivating them to pursue a career in STEM. In addition, this project has provided opportunities to post-baccalaureate students who are interested in a more technical career path. They receive hands-on training in chemical processing, laboratory safety, vacuum system maintenance, and operation of advanced instruments. As a result of this program, participants in the program have secured full-time employment as research and development staff both at Yale and outside Yale.
